actions-list.actionItem: The House adjourned. The next meeting is scheduled for 9:30 a.m. on February 2, 2023.
On motion to adjourn Agreed to by voice vote.
Mr. Clyde moved that the House do now adjourn.
The House has concluded all anticipated legislative business and has proceeded to Special Order speeches.
The House resumed with one minute speeches.

actions-list.header: Select Subcommittee on the Weaponization of the Federal Government
actions-list.actionItem: Pursuant to Section 1(a)(2)(A) of House Resolution 12, 118th Congress, the second order of the House of today, and the order of the House of January 9, 2023, the Speaker appointed the following members of the House to the Select Subcommittee on the Weaponization of the Federal Government: Mr. Jordan, Mr. Issa, Mr. Massie, Mr. Stewart, Ms. Stefanik, Mr. Johnson of Louisiana, Mr. Gaetz, Mr. Armstrong, Mr. Steube, Mr. Bishop of North Carolina, Mrs. Cammack, Ms. Hageman, Ms. Plaskett, Mr. Lynch, Ms. Sanchez, Ms. Wasserman Schultz, Mr. Connolly, Mr. Garamendi, Mr. Allred, Ms. Garcia of Texas and Mr. Goldman of New York.

actions-list.header: Select Subcommittee on the Coronavirus Pandemic
actions-list.actionItem: Pursuant to Section 4(a)(1)(B)(i) of House Resolution 5, 118th Congress, as amended by Section 1(d) of House Resolution 78, 118th Congress, and the order of the House of January 9, 2023, the Speaker appointed the following members of the House to the Select Subcommittee on the Coronavirus Pandemic: Mr. Wenstrup, Ms. Malliotakis, Mrs. Miller-Meeks, Mrs. Lesko, Mr. Cloud, Mr. Joyce of Pennsylvania, Ms. Greene of Georgia, Mr. Jackson of Texas, Mr. McCormick, Mr. Ruiz, Mrs. Dingell, Mr. Mfume, Ms. Ross and Mr. Robert Garcia of California.

actions-list.header: Select Committee on the Strategic Competition Between the United States and the Chinese Communist Party
actions-list.actionItem: Pursuant to Section 1(a)(2)(A) of House Resolution 11, 118th Congress, as amended by Section 1(b) of House Resolution 78, 118th, Congress, and the order of the House of January 9, 2023, the Speaker appointed the following members of the House to the Select Committtee on the Strategic Competition Between the United States and the Chinese Communist Party: Mr. Gallagher, Mr. Wittman, Mr. Luetkemeyer,Mr. Barr, Mr. Newhouse, Mr. Moolenaar, Mr. LaHood, Mr. Dunn of Florida, Mr. Banks, Mr. Johnson of South Dakota, Mrs. Steel, Mrs. Hinson, Mr. Gimenez, Mr. Krishnamoorthi, Ms. Castor of Florida, Mr. Carson, Mr. Moulton, Mr. Khanna, Mr. Kim of New Jersey, Ms. Sherrill, Ms. Stevens, Mr. Auchincloss, Mr. Torres of New York, and Ms. Brown.
Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence
The House proceeded with further one minute speeches.

Mr. Franklin, C. Scott asked unanimous consent that, notwithstanding section 1(a)(2)(A) of House Resolution 12 (as amended by section 1(c) of House Resolution 78), and the order of the House of today, the Select Subcommittee on the Weaponization of the Federal Government be composed of not more than 21 Members, Delegates, or the Resident Commissioner appointed by the Speaker, of whom not more than 9 shall be appointed in consultation with the Minority Leader. Agreed to without objection.
Mr. Franklin, C. Scott asked unanimous consent that when the House adjourns today, it adjourn to meet at 9:30 a.m. on February 2. Agreed to without objection.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to without objection.
Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 87 — "Electing Members to certain standing committees of the House of Representatives."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On passage Passed by the Yeas and Nays: 229

actions-list.actionItem: Considered as unfinished business. H.J. Res. 7 — "Relating to a national emergency declared by the President on March 13, 2020."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On passage Passed by the Yeas and Nays: 221

actions-list.actionItem: Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 139 — "To require Executive agencies to submit to Congress a study of the impacts of expanded telework and remote work by agency employees during the COVID-19 pandemic and a plan for the agency's future use of telework and remote work, and for other purposes."
The Chair announced the unfinished business was the question on passage of H.R. 139 and H.J. Res. 7, which had been debated earlier and on which further proceedings had been postponed.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of February 1.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is subject to the call of the Chair.

At the conclusion of debate on H.J. Res. 7, the Chair put the question on passage and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Graves (MO) demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H.J. Res. 7.
Rule provides for consideration of H.J. Res. 7, H.R. 139, H.R. 382 and H.R. 497. All bills are considered under a closed rule with one hour of general debate and one motion to recommit.
Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 75. H.J. Res. 7 — "Relating to a national emergency declared by the President on March 13, 2020."

At the conclusion of debate on H.R. 139, the Chair put the question on passage and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Comer demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H.R. 139.
Rule provides for consideration of H.J. Res. 7, H.R. 139, H.R. 382 and H.R. 497. All bills are considered under a closed rule with one hour of general debate and one motion to recommit.

Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 75. H.R. 139 — "To require Executive agencies to submit to Congress a study of the impacts of expanded telework and remote work by agency employees during the COVID-19 pandemic and a plan for the agency's future use of telework and remote work, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by recorded vote: 218
On ordering the previous question Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 219

actions-list.actionItem: Considered as unfinished business. H. Res. 83 — "Providing for consideration of the concurrent resolution (H. Con. Res. 9) denouncing the horrors of socialism, and providing for consideration of the resolution (H. Res. 76) removing a certain Member from a certain standing committee of the House."

The Chair announced the unfinished business was the question on ordering the previous question on H. Res. 83 and on agreeing to resolution, if ordered, which had been debated earlier and on which further proceedings had been postponed.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of February 1.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess for a period of less than 15 minutes.

At the conclusion of debate on H. Res. 83, the Chair put the question on ordering the previous question on H. Res. 83 and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. McGovern demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 83.

Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 83 — "Providing for consideration of the concurrent resolution (H. Con. Res. 9) denouncing the horrors of socialism, and providing for consideration of the resolution (H. Res. 76) removing a certain Member from a certain standing committee of the House."

Mr. Reschenthaler asked unanimous consent that, notwithstanding section 1(a)(2)(A) of House Resolution 12 (as amended by section 1(c) of House Resolution 78), the Select Subcommittee on the Weaponization of the Federal Government be composed of the chair and ranking minority member of the Committee on the Judiciary, together with not more than 19 other Members, Delegates, or the Resident Commissioner appointed by the Speaker, of whom not more than 8 shall be appointed in consultation with the minority leader. Agreed to without objection.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to without objection.
Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 84 — "Electing a Member to a certain standing committee of the House of Representatives."
The House proceeded with one minute speeches which by direction of the Chair, would be limited to 15 per side of the aisle.
The Chair designated Mr. Williams of TX to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal.  Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of February 1.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for approximately 12:00 p.m. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 12:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Mike Carey to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
